qas.question: When did Burke charge Hastings for impeachment?
What was the impeachment formally called?

answers.text: Article of Charge of High Crimes and Misdemeanors

qas.question: Like what creature did Burke say Hastings was 'devouring the dead'?
When did Hastings present his article against Burke?
What nickname was Burke given for his emotional indignation?

plausible_answers.text: both a 'spider of Hell' and a 'ravenous vulture devouring the carcasses of the dead'.

qas.question: What did the House of Commons compare Hastings to?
When did the House of Lords impeach Hastings?

context: On <a0_0><b5_0>4 April 1786<b5_0/><a0_0/>, Burke presented the Commons with the <a1_0>Article of Charge of High Crimes and Misdemeanors<a1_0/> against Hastings. The impeachment in Westminster Hall, which did not begin until <b8_0>14 February 1788<b8_0/>, would be the "first major public discursive event of its kind in England", bringing the morality and duty of imperialism to the forefront of public perception. Burke already was known for his eloquent rhetorical skills and his involvement in the trial only enhanced its popularity and significance. Burke's indictment, fuelled by emotional indignation, branded Hastings a '<b6_0>captain-general of iniquity<b6_0/>'; who never dined without 'creating a famine'; whose heart was 'gangrened to the core', and who resembled <b7_0>both a 'spider of Hell' and a '<a4_0>ravenous vulture<a4_0/> devouring the carcasses of the dead'.<b7_0/> The <a3_0>House of Commons<a3_0/> eventually impeached Hastings, but subsequently, the <a2_0><b9_0>House of Lords<b9_0/><a2_0/> acquitted him of all charges.
